key_points: Alec Baldwin, involved in a fatal shooting on the 'Rust' movie set, likely won't face criminal or civil liability as an actor, but might as a producer.
Legal experts foresee significant legal and possibly criminal repercussions for Baldwin and other leadership roles on the set.
The incident resulted in the death of cinematographer Halyna Hutchins and injury to director Joel Souza.
Negligence on the set was highlighted by law and gun policy expert Adam Winkler, emphasizing a duty to ensure crew safety.
Assistant director Dave Halls handed Baldwin the gun, mistakenly declaring it safe, leading to the fatal accident.
Previous safety issues and accidental discharges were reported on the set, raising concerns about negligence.
Rust Movie Productions claimed unawareness of any official safety complaints and pledged to review procedures.
Legal professionals doubt criminal charges will be pursued due to the potential impact on New Mexico's film industry.
Insurance might cover accidental events but not negligence claims, with an investigation to determine liability.
The tragedy could prompt safety reforms, but experts suggest such incidents are preventable with existing firearm safety regulations.
spokespersons: Adam Winkler (Professor, UCLA School of Law and gun policy expert)
Nina Marino (Defense Attorney, Co-founder of Kaplan Marino law firm)
Julie Shapiro (Law Professor and Director of Loyola Law School's Entertainment and Media Law Institute)
Jeff Harris (Founding Partner, Harris Lowry Manton LLP)
